author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Stand up and run: The catcher's drill that sealed a win for the Rockies
summary: If the Rockies are going to win the first National League West title in their history, they’re going to have to win the games they’re leading in the ninth inning, and sometimes that’s going to take the tiny efforts that no one notices, the ones that sometimes everyone notices.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Texas A&M beats Vanderbilt 3-1 in SEC Tournament
summary: HOOVER, Ala. (AP) — Kaylor Chafin and Nolan Hoffman combined to scatter eight hits Tuesday as 11th-seeded Texas A&M eliminated No. 6 seed Vanderbilt 3-1 on the first day of the Southeastern Conference Tournament. Texas A&M withstood an hour-long rain delay to advance to the double-elimination portion of the tournament. The Aggies (37-19) face No. 3 seed Georgia (37-17) on Wednesday. Chafin (5-0) struck out five and allowed six hits, one run and one walk in six innings. Hoffman yielded two hits in three innings of shutout relief for his 13th save. Vanderbilt (31-25) led 1-0 before Texas A&M scored twice in the fifth inning. Cole Bedford singled home Allonte Wingate to tie the game and later scored

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Aaron Judge shuts down Home Run Derby talk: Can't force me
summary: ARLINGTON, Texas. — Don't look for Aaron Judge in the Home Run Derby during the All-Star break in July. In March, the Yankees right fielder said he was leaning toward not defending the title he won a year ago. Tuesday, before the Yankees faced the Rangers at Globe Life Park, Judge told The Post he will skip the event. “There is no need to do it,'' Judge said about defending his title, which he copped a year ago in Miami. Until MLB received official word that Judge would be in the Derby last year, the league made it very clear Judge's participation would be a boost to the made-for-TV event. So, what if MLB puts pressure on Judge, who commissioner Rob Manfred said at last year's All-Star Game could

author: nanook
title: Mets sign OF Jose Bautista to one-year major league deal

author: DeltaBravo
title: What changed for Madison Bumgarner when he faced hitters in Houston
summary: HOUSTON–Madison Bumgarner is set for his first rehab start on Saturday, and after facing hitters on Tuesday at Minute Maid Park, he's feeling encouraged about his upcoming outing in Sacramento. Bumgarner said he struggled to command his breaking balls in previous bullpens, but didn't have that issue against Gregor Blanco and Miguel Gomez in a 30-pitch session on Tuesday. “Everything was working good, the breaking balls were doing what they were supposed to with a lot more consistency today than the previous bullpens,” Bumgarner said. “We'll continue to see forward strides I guess and see things getting better each time I get out there.” Bumgarner hinted that his offspeed offerings weren't quite

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Yankees are prime candidate to make play for Rangers pitcher Cole Hamels
summary: ARLINGTON, Texas — Rangers ace Cole Hamels starts Tuesday against Yankees' Domingo German, and the 34-year-old lefty (2-4, 3.48 ERA, nine starts) will be a popular trade target among contenders. Naturally, the Yankees are a prime candidate to make a play for him by the July 31 deadline. “Shoot, I helped them get a World Series in '09,'' Hamels told reporters earlier Monday, referencing his loss in Game 3. “So, I'm sure they like me.'' Hamels also has a limited no-trade clause, is making $22.5 million this year, and his $20 million club option for 2019 would kick in if he reaches certain performance incentives. If not, there's a $6 million buyout. And the Yankees' starting pitching depth remains

author: third_watch
title: Giants make roster move, why Pablo Sandoval will start Wednesday
summary: HOUSTON–After he hit home runs in each of his first two rehab games, Mac Williamson appeared poised to rejoin the Giants on their upcoming road trip. While it's likely Williamson will be back at some point during the Giants three-city trip, he was not added to the roster ahead of Tuesday's contest in Houston. Instead, the Giants called up left-handed reliever Josh Osich from Triple-A Sacramento to replace right-hander Jose Valdez, who was placed on the 10-day disabled list with right elbow inflammation. Osich tossed 4 2/3 innings of scoreless ball for the River Cats after being optioned following a stint on the disabled list with a hip strain. The southpaw enjoyed a strong spring training and

author: captainunderoos
title: Alex Cora Found Awesome Way To Make Rafael Devers Stop Chasing Pitches
summary: Why give your player a tip when you can pay him for the whole meal? That's the philosophy of Boston Red Sox manager Alex Cora, who apparently resorted to some old-fashioned wagering to help Rafael Devers kick a bad habit. During an appearance Monday on ESPN's “Baseball Tonight with Buster Olney” podcast, Cora revealed the proposal he brought to his rookie third baseman late last week. “Rafi, he's been chasing a lot of pitches lately in the last month,” Cora told Olney. “This week, I asked him, 'Rafi, what's your favorite restaurant?' And he told me. … And I go, 'OK, let's make a deal: You give me X amount of money every time you chase a pitch out of the zone, and then I'll give you a gift certificate

author: DeltaBravo
title: How on-fire Yankees can get even scarier
summary: The Yankees are on a 114-win pace, which exceeds even the grandest predictions for this season. That emphasizes collective excellence. But which individual Yankees are exceeding expectations? For if a team were on pace to equal its greatest regular-season win total ever, you would think a bunch of their players were en route to their best seasons as well. But that mainly is not the case with these Yankees, making it possible they have an even higher ceiling. Which may be necessary to reach since the Red Sox are on pace for a franchise-record 110 wins. Can you imagine winning 100-plus games and being at the mercy of a one-and-done wild-card game? That beats the fate of, say, the 1993 Giants, who

author: third_watch
title: Seattle Mariners go back to the future with 'Turn Ahead the Clock Night'
summary: The Seattle Mariners are reviving one of the most unforgettable promotion nights in MLB history this June.

title: MLB Power Rankings: Week 8
summary: The young, surging Braves have climbed into the top four of Drew Silva's weekly MLB Power Rankings. See where all 30 teams stand.

title: Closing Time: Tyler O'Neill claims some turf
summary: The Cardinals had a big-name outfield ready to go, but Tyler O'Neill is crashing the party.

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: MLB trade rumors: Which starting pitchers could be available by the deadline?
summary: I know what you're thinking: "Joe — it's May, you psychopath! Why are you writing this?" Why? Because it's always trade deadline season. Always. Just peruse Twitter: Fans of certain teams are already playing armchair GM, making trades for front-end starters while licking the Doritos cheese residue off their fingers. While the amount of quality starting pitching that could be available is pretty impressive, there are plenty of questions. Here's a look at starting pitching that may be available heading into the trade deadline. Chris Archer, Rays Trade possibility:  C+ 10 starts (59 1/3 IP), 5.01 ERA (4.25 FIP), 1.348 WHIP, 3.00 K/BB ratio It's interesting to think that once upon a time — albeit

author: DeltaBravo
title: Derek Jeter's latest unforced error makes him look petty
summary: The way Derek Jeter wants his ownership of the Marlins to be portrayed is: He is working 24/7, but when anything goes awry, it isn't his fault. Even for legends, it doesn't work that way when you are running a franchise. Errors are not just scored E-6 anymore, but all fall under Jeter's name in the boxscore. So far, Jeter's part ownership of the Marlins has been like Single-A Greensboro in 1993, when he had 56 errors. He arrived in Miami to dismantle. He traded the National League MVP Giancarlo Stanton at a discount and now has one of the worst teams in baseball. Meanwhile, he routinely grounds into PR double plays. The latest flare-up is the Marlins denying a media credential to South Florida

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Juan Soto's former teammates went bonkers after his first MLB home run

author: nanook
title: Colorado Avalanche Draft Targets: Rounds 1-3
summary: Thanks to the Matt Duchene trade, the Colorado Avalanche hold an extra second round pick in the 2018 NHL Entry Draft. For a team that has been known to trade away an abundance of picks over the past few seasons, having three picks in the top-60 is a welcome novelty. Once you get outside of the top-3, this year's draft is as wide open as any. There are a number of players that could be drafted anywhere from #7 to the early 20s. With such a wide open group, it's hard to pin down exactly who will be available to the Avalanche at #16. Joe Sakic and his group will likely have a rather fluid draft board with a handful of hopeful targets in the first round. There are many fans that would like certain

author: third_watch
title: Daily Red Sox Links: Figuring out Dustin Pedroia's spot in the lineup
summary: There are a couple holes in the Boston Red Sox's lineup. They are primarily near the bottom of the order at center field and catcher. Both Jackie Bradley Jr. and Christian Vazquez, the primary options at those positions, are hanging out below the Mendoza Line, which is troubling. However, the negative effects have not been as paramount because of all that mashing from J.D. Martinez and Mookie Betts. For now, Cora has been able to hide Bradley Jr., Vazquez as well as Eduardo Nunez at the bottom of the order while generally sticking with a pretty consistent lineup card. But putting together a good lineup is difficult, and not just if you are the Mets. Matchups need to be considered, plus there

author: DeltaBravo
title: Prospects for all 30 teams you should be stoked to see in 2018
summary: A quarter of the baseball season has passed us by, and, due to combinations of injuries at the big league level and hot starts on the farm, it's becoming clearer which prospects have even better chances to make their major league debuts this year. Below is one potential call-up from each club whom you should anticipate and be excited about and who might have an impact on a playoff race while providing you a glimpse of a hopeful future. Arizona Diamondbacks: RHP Yoan Lopez. Lopez's tenure had been little more than infamous until 2017, when his fastball velocity ticked up 5 mph. Once a prospect albatross teams had a hard time scouting due to inconsistent playing time, Lopez is now throwing 95-99

author: DeltaBravo
title: Martinez starts road to returning
summary: DeJONG EXAMINED Shortstop Paul DeJong, who had left hand surgery Friday night after being hit by a pitch the night before, was looked at by a hand specialist Monday and Girsch said, “We don't know yet” as to his return. But a fair guess would be a comparison to Pittsburgh infielder Josh Harrison, who also had a break in his left little finger and came back Sunday after being out five weeks. It had been projected that Harrison would miss six weeks. LYONS, KELLLY TO BE BACK SOON Lefthander Tyler Lyons, throwing his second rehab outing for Class AA Springfield, allowed a two-run homer while retiring two of the four hitters he faced Monday. Girsch said Lyons, who had a mid-back strain, “is probably

author: third_watch
title: Around the Empire: Yankees news
summary: MLB.com | Bryan Hoch: Another day, another historic dinger or five. The Yankees are hitting all the dingers they possibly can lately. Gleyber Torres had his first multi-homer game of his young career. Torres is the youngest Yankee to hit two dingers in one game since Mickey Mantle. Yes, THAT Mickey Mantle. Also, the Yankees have hit at least four home runs in the last three games. If only we had some sort of nickname for this team. Something that let us know their stadium's location, as well as had an alternate name for home runs. Alas, I'm at a loss. Cut4 | Adrian Garro: The Yankees do many things well. They hit dingers, they pitch well, and they hit dingers. Another thing they do well is remind

author: third_watch
title: Rafael Palmeiro, 53, slugs home run for Cleburne Railroaders

author: third_watch
title: Torres homers twice of Colon as Yankees beat Rangers 10-5
summary: Gleyber Torres was only three months old when Bartolo Colon made his major league debut. Now Torres is a rookie second baseman helping the New York Yankees in a power stretch never accomplished by past Bronx Bombers - none of those teams with Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris or Reggie Jackson. Torres hit two of the four Yankees homers off Colon, and they had five overall in a 10-5 win Monday night at Texas.

author: nanook
title: Hochman: Cards' O'Neill is too hot to take out of lineup
summary: “The biggest thing with Tyler coming through the minor leagues was his power, and the fact that it's playing now? It's indescribable,” she said.“And in St. Louis? You can't ask for a more picturesque scene than to have these fans on their feet, standing ovation and him going to that top step and waving his helmet. It's unfathomable. … And I know for Ty, fan engagement is huge for him. It pumps him up, makes him feel great.” “Ty and I have this thing where it's quality at-bats — that's the focus,” she said. “We actually had a talk last night. It's not about going in the box and hitting a home run; it's about going into the box and seeing it pitch by pitch. The ones that do look good, see what
